sources: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish (NMDGF)
notes: Regulations are subject to change. Always verify with official state agencies before fishing.
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations.
Special regulations apply to specific water bodies - check location-specific rules.
License requirements and fees vary by residency status and age.

license_requirements.notes: Licenses available through vendors, NMDGF offices, and online at wildlife.dgf.nm.gov
special_validations: Second Rod Validation available (allows use of two rods)
Multiple rods beyond two prohibited at all times

general_restrictions.rod_limits: One rod without validation, or two rods with Second Rod Validation. More than two rods prohibited.
prohibited_methods: Bow fishing and spearfishing for game fish not allowed in rivers, streams, Special Trout Water, or Trophy Bass Water
general_restrictions.special_restrictions: On San Juan River Special Trout Water, cannot fish with more than two flies on a single line

species.minimum_size_notes: 14-inch minimum size limit statewide; Trophy Bass Waters have different limits
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 black bass per day combined (largemouth, smallmouth, spotted bass). Trophy Bass Waters: 2 per day, 14 inches or longer
species.possession_notes: 10 fish statewide; Trophy Bass Waters: 2 fish
species.geographic_restrictions: Trophy Bass Waters (Bill Evans Lake, Clayton Lake, Lake Roberts) have special regulations
species.special_regulations: Trophy Bass Waters: 2 fish per day minimum 14 inches, spearfishing and bow fishing prohibited for largemouth bass
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.minimum_size_notes: 12-inch minimum statewide; 14-inch minimum at Conchas and Ute Reservoirs; no length limit in Rio Grande (Rio Arriba and Taos counties)
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 black bass per day combined (included in total black bass limit)
species.geographic_restrictions: Conchas and Ute Reservoirs: 14-inch minimum; Rio Grande (Taos/Rio Arriba Counties): no minimum
species.special_regulations: Size limits vary by water body
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.minimum_size_notes: 14-inch minimum size limit (included in black bass regulations)
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 black bass per day combined (included in total black bass limit)
species.special_regulations: Included in statewide black bass regulations
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.bag_limit_notes: 15 catfish per day (all species except bullheads); Special Summer Catfish Waters: 2 per day; Animas and San Juan Rivers: no limit
species.possession_notes: 30 fish statewide; Special Summer Catfish Waters: 4 fish; Animas and San Juan Rivers: no limit
species.season_description: Year-round; Special Summer Catfish Waters stocked May-September
species.geographic_restrictions: Special Summer Catfish Waters (Alto Lake, Alumni Pond, Bataan Lake, etc.) have 2 fish limit. Animas River and San Juan River (below Navajo Dam) have no bag or possession limits
species.special_regulations: No trotlines on many waters. Special Summer Catfish Waters have reduced limits.
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.bag_limit_notes: 15 catfish per day (all species except bullheads, combined limit)
species.special_regulations: Included in combined catfish daily limit
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.minimum_size_notes: No statewide minimum size limit; some waters may have specific restrictions
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 trout per day (combined limit for brown, brook, rainbow, Gila trout, kokanee). No more than 2 lake trout and/or 2 cutthroat trout may be included in limit. Special waters may have different limits.
species.geographic_restrictions: Tingley Beach Central and Children's Pond: 4 trout. Laguna del Campo, Red River Hatchery Pond, Red River City Ponds, Goose Lake, Rio Grande (Elephant Butte to Caballo Lake): 3 trout
species.special_regulations: Special Trout Waters may have reduced bag limits or catch-and-release only regulations. Check specific water body regulations.
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 trout per day (combined limit with other trout species). No more than 2 lake trout and/or 2 cutthroat trout may be included.
species.geographic_restrictions: Some Special Trout Waters have different limits
species.special_regulations: Included in combined trout daily limit
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 trout per day (combined limit with other trout species)
species.special_regulations: Included in combined trout daily limit
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 cutthroat trout per day (within the 5-trout total daily limit). Rio Grande cutthroat is New Mexico's state fish.
species.possession_notes: No more than 2 cutthroat trout within the 10-trout possession limit
species.special_regulations: Limited to 2 per day within overall 5-trout limit. State fish of New Mexico.
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

species.minimum_size_notes: No statewide minimum size limit where harvest allowed
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 trout per day (combined limit with other trout species) where harvest is allowed. Many Gila trout waters are catch-and-release only.
species.season_description: Year-round where open; many waters catch-and-release only
species.geographic_restrictions: Endemic to New Mexico and Arizona. Many recovery streams are catch-and-release only or closed to fishing.
species.special_regulations: Listed as threatened species. Many waters with Gila trout are designated catch-and-release only to support recovery efforts. Check specific water body regulations.
species.regulation_source: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish

contact_information.agency_name: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish
contact_information.emergency_orders: Check website for current Emergency Orders and Proclamations

license_requirements.freshwater: Sport fishing license required for age 10+
license_requirements.notes: Licenses available online, through vendors, and at AZGFD offices at azgfd.gov
license_requirements.special_permits: Urban Fishing License available for Community Fishing Program waters

general_restrictions.possession_limits: Possession limits are twice the daily bag limits unless otherwise noted
general_restrictions.live_bait_restrictions: No live baitfish may be used or possessed while on any waters in Coconino, Apache, Navajo, Pima and Cochise counties
general_restrictions.measurement: Most waters do not have length limits; check Special Regulations for specific waters

species.minimum_size_notes: No statewide minimum size; some waters have 13-inch minimum (Graham County Fairgrounds Pond, Patterson Ponds, Cowpuncher Pond)
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 bass per day (any combination of largemouth and smallmouth). Some waters have different limits (Lake Powell: 5 largemouth; Bear Canyon Lake: unlimited)
species.possession_notes: 12 bass (twice daily limit); varies by location
species.geographic_restrictions: Lake Powell: 5 fish limit. Bear Canyon Lake, Black Canyon Lake, Chevelon Canyon Lake: unlimited. Some urban waters: 1 fish with 13-inch minimum.
species.special_regulations: Commission Order 40 contains special regulations for specific waters. Check before fishing.

species.minimum_size_notes: No statewide minimum size; check special regulations for specific waters
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 bass per day (any combination of largemouth and smallmouth). Lake Powell: 20 smallmouth bass allowed.
species.possession_notes: 12 bass (twice daily limit); Lake Powell: 40 fish
species.geographic_restrictions: Lake Powell: 20 fish daily limit. Bear Canyon Lake: unlimited. Various special regulations apply to specific waters.
species.special_regulations: Check Commission Order 40 for water-specific regulations

species.bag_limit_notes: 10 catfish per day (any combination of channel and flathead). Some waters unlimited (Bear Canyon Lake, Black Canyon Lake). Lake Mead/Mohave: proposed increase to 25 (pending 2026 approval).
species.possession_notes: 20 catfish (twice daily limit); varies by location
species.geographic_restrictions: Bear Canyon Lake: unlimited. Apache Lake, Canyon Lake, Saguaro Lake: 5 catfish with bow and arrow. Lake Mary Lower: 4 channel catfish. Show Low Creek: 2 catfish.
species.special_regulations: Proposed regulation changes for Lake Mead and Lake Mohave to increase limit to 25. Bow fishing allowed at specific lakes.

species.bag_limit_notes: 10 catfish per day (any combination of channel and flathead). Some waters unlimited.
species.geographic_restrictions: Bear Canyon Lake: unlimited flathead and channel catfish
species.special_regulations: Included in combined catfish daily limit

species.minimum_size_notes: No statewide minimum size limit; most waters have no length limits
species.bag_limit_notes: 4 trout per day (any combination including rainbow, cutthroat, brown, brook, tiger, Gila, Apache trout, and grayling)
species.season_description: Open year-round statewide; stocking occurs October through April
species.geographic_restrictions: Check Community Fishing Program waters and Special Regulation waters for specific restrictions
species.special_regulations: Arizona Game & Fish Department stocks trout from October through April. Check designated Community Fishing Program waters for any length limits.

species.bag_limit_notes: 4 trout per day (any combination, included in total trout limit)
species.special_regulations: Included in combined trout daily limit

species.bag_limit_notes: 4 trout per day (any combination, included in total trout limit)
species.special_regulations: Included in combined trout daily limit

species.minimum_size_notes: No minimum size where harvest is allowed
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 Apache trout per day where harvest is allowed (within 4-trout total daily limit). State fish of Arizona.
species.season_description: Year-round where open; limited waters allow harvest
species.geographic_restrictions: Endemic to Arizona. Limited distribution in White Mountains area.
species.special_regulations: Apache trout is Arizona's state fish and a threatened species. Limited to 2 per day where harvest is permitted. Many waters are catch-and-release only.

species.minimum_size_notes: No minimum size where harvest is allowed
species.bag_limit_notes: 4 trout per day (any combination) where harvest is allowed. Many Gila trout waters are catch-and-release only.
species.season_description: Year-round where open; many recovery streams have special regulations
species.geographic_restrictions: KP Creek (Greenlee County) closed to angling to protect Gila trout (2026). Bear Wallow Creek, Hayground Creek, Stinky Creek: catch-and-release only May 1-Dec 31. Dude and Grapevine Creeks: seasonal catch-and-release. East Verde River, Frye Mesa Reservoir, Watson Lake, Lynx Lake, Goldwater Lake: year-round fishing allowed.
species.special_regulations: Threatened species. New 2026 regulations close KP Creek. Bear Wallow, Hayground, and Stinky Creeks: catch-and-release only with artificial fly and lure, single-pointed barbless hooks, May 1-Dec 31. Multiple recovery streams managed for conservation.

urban_fishing_program.description: Arizona Community Fishing Program offers 50+ fishing waters in communities throughout Arizona
urban_fishing_program.target_audience: Families, new anglers, occasional and experienced anglers
urban_fishing_program.license: Urban Fishing License available for Community Fishing Program waters

contact_information.emergency_orders: Check website for current regulation changes and Commission Order updates

important_reminders: Always check for Emergency Orders and Proclamations before fishing
Special regulations apply to specific water bodies - verify location-specific rules
Trophy waters, Special Trout Waters, and recovery streams have unique regulations
Native and threatened species (Apache trout, Gila trout) have protective measures
License requirements vary by age and residency status
Possession limits typically twice the daily bag limit unless otherwise noted
measurement_guidelines: Total length is measured from tip of snout to end of tail
Slot limits indicate keepable size range (e.g., 15-20 inches means fish between those sizes)
When in doubt, release the fish - conservation ensures future fishing opportunities

conservation_notes.apache_trout: Arizona state fish and threatened species. Limited harvest allowed. Endemic to Arizona White Mountains.
conservation_notes.gila_trout: Threatened species endemic to New Mexico and Arizona. Many recovery streams are catch-and-release only. Reclassified from endangered to threatened in 2006.
conservation_notes.rio_grande_cutthroat: New Mexico state fish. Limited to 2 per day to support population conservation.
conservation_notes.trophy_bass_waters: Trophy Bass Waters in New Mexico (Bill Evans Lake, Clayton Lake, Lake Roberts) managed to produce largemouth bass over 5 pounds.

data_coverage.focus: Freshwater species commonly targeted by recreational anglers in Southwest region

recommended_resources: eRegulations mobile app for offline access
Fish Rules app for quick regulation lookup
Local bait and tackle shops for current information
